statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Utah 74, Texas State 59
article.story: SALT LAKE CITY (AP) -- Sophomore transfer Johnnie Bryant had a game-high 21 points to lead Utah to a 74-59 win over Texas State Friday night in the season opener for both teams. Senior Bryant Markson added 19 points for Utah (1-0), who played its first game without last season's Wooden Award winner Andrew Bogut, now in the NBA. Brandon Bush led Texas State (0-1) with 15 points. He was one of six freshmen who suited up for the Bobcats. The Utes had a tough time pulling away from Texas State. After jumping out to an 8-0 lead to begin the game, Texas State battled back to make it 8-7, and only trailed by two at halftime. The back-and-forth continued in the second half until the Utes went on a run midway through, eventually taking their first double-digit lead at 51-41 with 10:45 to go in the game. The Utes eventually built a lead as big as 19-points as the Bobcats struggled to get back in the game. The Utes had a big advantage from the foul line, sinking 21-of-31 attempts, compared to the Bobcats who only attempted 16, making 10. Utah is now 85-13 all time in home openers.
